Award.AwardTitle: Building Geometric Databases for Anatomy-Based Spatial Queries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant aims to develop an atlas-based database architecture suited for organizing 3D anatomical images for efficient spatial queries. Utilizing a new form of atlas, the project will develop tools for accurate and efficient alignment of 3D images collected from a large number of subjects with varying anatomical shapes. The resulting database will facilitate convenient, web-based spatial queries of functional, metabolic, mechanical, and structural data within customizable regions of interest among stored images. As a test-bed application, the project will construct two web-based databases of 3D gene expression patterns for the mouse brain and heart from stacks of 2D tissue sections.

At the heart of the architecture is a new type of geometric atlas, represented as a subdivision mesh, which models the partitioning and interior of an anatomical region of interest, such as the brain. The geometric and multi-resolution structure of the atlas allows for flexible registration onto individual subjects with varying anatomical shapes, and enables fast, multi-level comparison of registered data. The tools for constructing, populating, and querying atlas-based databases will be made freely available online to be easily integrated with existing databases for augmented spatial querying capabilities.

The use of biological imaging in science continues to grow, and it has thus become critical to many research efforts to be able to efficiently utilize the enormous resources of spatial information being generated. The gene expression databases resulted from the project will enable querying and clustering of genes based on similarity of 3D expression patterns, which may lead to significant breakthroughs in understanding biological processes. The long term goal of this project is to facilitate collaborative knowledge discovery across subjects, image modalities, and geographical locations.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to provide key technologies that would enable comparison of spatial data (e.g., gene expression patterns, cell density distribution, fluorescence distribution, etc.) collected from different specimens over a common anatomical region. The intellectual merit of the research resides in the proposal of a novel type of 3D anatomical atlas and the associated methods for creating the atlas, registering spatial data onto the atlas, and querying the resulting atlas-based database.

During the course of the project, computer scientists and biologists from three organizations, Washington University in St. Louis, University of Houston, and Battelle Northwest, collaborated to develop a pipeline of methods that take raw imaging data all the way to a fully queryable spatial database. The pipeline starts with imaging processing algorithms that remove artifacts in the input images and preserve the integrity of biological information. A multi-tissue deformable anatomical atlas represented as a volumetric subdivision mesh is then constructed from a reference data set using novel geometric algorithms accompanied with interactive graphical interfaces. Next, the atlas is registered onto newly collected data set, again using automated algorithms with interactive user guidance. Finally, an online database is built that allows fully customizable spatial queries into the registered data. The power of the novel atlas-based approach is demonstrated in a testbed application of online database of 3D gene expression patterns over the mouse brain.

The methods and tools developed in the project are available as freely distributed software and applets, which are maintained (with sample data, documentation, and video guides) on Geneatlas.org.


Last Modified: 08/07/2012
Modified by: Tao Ju
